explanation:
- OS_object_token_t: Needed to know the underlying type/const-qualification of the object token (scalar vs struct) and whether any operations on it require a mutable token. This determines if the const on the token parameter is appropriate/possible.
- OS_bin_sem_prop_t: Required to inspect the fields (especially the "value" member) to confirm that sem_prop is actually written to by the function and therefore cannot be a pointer-to-const. Also to check whether any fields could/should be const.
- OS_impl_binsem_internal_record_t: Needed to see the type and const-qualification of the "current_value" member and other members; to determine if reading sem->current_value from the table requires any mutable access to the record or its containing table.
- OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET: The macro/function expansion must be examined to see whether it mutates its arguments or takes addresses/produces lvalues that would force a non-const token, or whether it only reads the token (allowing const). Macros can hide non-const requirements.
- OS_impl_bin_sem_table: Definition/type of the table used by OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET may impose requirements (e.g., if the table access API requires non-const indices or mutable access), so its declaration/usage must be checked.
- OS_ObjectIndexFromToken: This function is likely invoked by the table-access macro; its prototype/definition is needed to see whether it accepts a pointer-to-const or a non-const pointer (i.e., whether it would force removal of const from token).

Together these symbols let an analyst determine whether any called macro/function or accessed data requires mutation of the memory pointed to by the parameters (which would prohibit adding const), or whether the token pointer could/should be const as per MISRA rule.
